fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and let c\in C be an object. By the Yoneda lemma, a choice of x\in Fc corresponds to a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\alpha _x} F. Such a choice expresses a universal property of c if \alpha _x is an isomorphism, and hence a representation. In this case, x is called a universal element.
The analogous dual definition applies to presheaves.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

Let D\xrightarrow {U} C be a functor and c\in C an object. Then a U-free object on c represents the functor C(c, U-). Explicitly, it is an object d\in D equipped with a bijection C(c, Uz)\cong D(d, z) natural in z\in D. In other words, it satisfies the universal property that Fc would have, for a left adjoint F to U.

Dually, a U-cofree object on c represents the functor C(U-, c). Explicitly, it is an object d\in D equipped with a bijection C(Uz, c)\cong D(z, d) natural in z\in D: it satisfies the universal property that Fc would have, for a right adjoint F to U.

fr:title.text: Kan extension › universal property of Kan extensions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kan extension › universal property of Kan extensions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the universal property of a left Kan extension asks for a bijection E^C(F, GK)\cong E^D(\operatorname *{Lan}_K F, G) natural in D\xrightarrow {G} E: \operatorname *{Lan}_K F represents the functor E^D\xrightarrow {K^*} E^C\xrightarrow {\operatorname {Hom}(F, -)} Set.
A colimit of a diagram is a universal cocone.

By the definition of universal elements, a colimit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{colim} D\in C and a cocone D \xrightarrow {\lambda } \operatorname *{colim} D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} D, -)\cong \operatorname *{Cocone}_D.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.

Suppose we are given a representation C(c, -)\overset {\alpha }{\cong } F of a functor C\xrightarrow {F} D. Then by the construction of the bijection in the Yoneda lemma, we can compute the universal element characterizing this representation as \alpha _c(1_c).

Let c and d be objects in a category C, and suppose that F and x express universal properties of both c and d. Then there is a canonical isomorphism c\cong d; in particular, a unique isomorphism that commutes with the corresponding representations.
We are thus justified in referring to "the universal object with an x."

Let C(c, -)\overset {\alpha _x}{\cong } F and C(d, -)\overset {\beta _x}{\cong } F be the corresponding natural isomorphisms given by definition of a universal property. Then their composition gives an isomorphism C(c, -)\cong C(d, -), which lifts to an isomorphism c\cong d by the Yoneda lemma.
A presheaf on a category C is a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\to Set. The presheaf category \hat {C} is the functor category Set^{C^\text {op}} of presheaves on C.

A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if there exists an object c\in C and a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\cong F to the covariant hom-functor. A representation of F is a choice of such data.
Dually, a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if there exists an object c\in C and a natural isomorphism C(-, c)\cong F to the contravariant hom-functor.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set be a presheaf and A\in C an object. Let y be the Yoneda embedding and \hat {C} be the presheaf category. Then \hat {C}(yA, F)\cong FA, and this bijection is natural in F and A. Furthermore, the image of a natural transformation yA\xrightarrow {\alpha } F under this bijection is \alpha _A(1_A).
Dually, let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and A\in C an object. Then \operatorname {Hom}(C(A, -), F)\cong FA.
We prove the contravariant (presheaf) case. The proof is in three parts: the bijection, and the two naturality claims.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A natural isomorphism is an isomorphism in a functor category. Explicitly, it is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.
